level.text: Each child-placing agency shall maintain adoptive family records which shall contain the following:
The application with photograph;
The home study;
Medical records of each family member and financial verifications;
Documentation of the agency’s contacts with at least three (3) references;
Criminal and child abuse records and reports of family members;
Summary narrative of the pre-placement and post placement contacts with the adoptive family and the adopted child;
Verification of each marriage and divorce of the applicants;
The adoptive placement agreement;
Each legal document pertaining to adoption;
A statement signed by the applicant stating that he or she has reviewed agency policies and procedures;
All correspondence related to the adoption;
Identifying information on each child placed in the home;
A physician’s report on the health of the child prior to finalization, and
A report of the supervisory period to include:
Significant changes in family circumstances since the initial home study such as employment, place of residence, birth, death, and illness;
The child’s emotional adjustment and the family’s response;
Acceptance of placement by the extended family and community;
The health, physical, and intellectual development of the child;
Observations of the child placed regarding daily activities such as sleeping, eating, playing, school, and day care;
Cultural adaptation of the child including language adaptation and habits; and
Any information that completely describes the child’s overall adjustment as well as a summary and recommendations which may include the need for outside resources.
Each child-placing agency shall maintain individual records for each child placed in an adoptive home which contain:
Identifying information, including the name, birthdate, place of birth, sex, race, height, weight, hair color, eye color, identifying remarks, social security number, and photographs;
Copies of the legal documents of importance to the child, such as birth certificate and any court disposition;
Social, physical and mental history of the child’s biological family, if available;
Records of immunizations and dental care; medical reports and physical and mental history of the child, as required;
A summary which reflects the dates of contact, initial assessment, case plan, and content of the worker’s visits;
Information on the circumstances which led to the decision to place the child, the agency’s involvement with the parent(s), including services offered, provided, or rejected;
Educational records;
Summary of the case reviews which reflect contacts with each family member in relation to the case plan as well as the achievements or changes in the goals;
Summary of any administrative or outside service reviews on the progress of each child toward the goal determination;
Summary of the child’s contacts with family members which reflect the quality of the relationships as well as how the child is coping with them; and
History of care including names of care-givers, addresses, and dates of care.
Each child-placing agency shall ensure that upon discharge a child’s record contains the following:
A discharge summary showing services provided during care, the growth and accomplishments, assessed needs to be met, and recommended services to meet these goals;
Dates of and reason for discharge, and the name, address, telephone number, and relationship of the person or agency to whom the child is discharged; and
Aftercare plans which specify the responsibility for follow-through on the care of the child.
